results.content: This course met my expectation - it provided an introduction to Quasar.  I am contemplating re-architecting my main application to something new, and took this to discover if Quasar might work.  I am fairly proficient at Vue, but I did learn a couple of neat Vue tricks along the way, and of course how Quasar works.  This course will not be enough to really build a full blown application, particularly on platforms other than web, because its a fairly simple app and there were not a lot of challenges fixing the build configs for mobile and desktop.  I suspect in real life there will be considerable additional challenges to build mobile and desktop apps.  Also, the app is built without any automated testing process, so no help if you want to do TDD or a CI workflow in a Quasar project.  Finally, the app uses Firebase as a backend, but does not go through any challenges if other backends were used, such as node, Laravel, etc.  Danny was well spoken and engaging, the screen easy to read, and the sound mostly ok, though there was some variations here and there.  5 stars
results.content_html: This course met my expectation - it provided an introduction to Quasar. This course will not be enough to really build a full blown application, particularly on platforms other than web, because its a fairly simple app and there were not a lot of challenges fixing the build configs for mobile and desktop. I suspect in real life there will be considerable additional challenges to build mobile and desktop apps. Also, the app is built without any automated testing process, so no help if you want to do TDD or a CI workflow in a Quasar project. Finally, the app uses Firebase as a backend, but does not go through any challenges if other backends were used, such as node, Laravel, etc. Danny was well spoken and engaging, the screen easy to read, and the sound mostly ok, though there was some variations here and there. 5 stars

results.content: I have watched about half of the course so far. This course is an excellent resource for anybody who wants to learn Vue.js and Quasar framework. I have already used both vue.js and quasar before watching this course (I have deployed an App on Google Play Store and AppStore) and to be honest I have to admit I am still learning new tricks and new good practices about those two very powerful frameworks. Therefore, I definitely recommend this course to those who wants to start learning Vue.js and Quasar Framework and also to those who have already some experience like me and want to improve their knowledge. I think the only prerequisite for this course is a basic knowledge of vanilla javascript and some very basic knowledge of functional programming. Last but not least all the videos about icon and splash generation necessary to all the platforms (mac osx, linux, windows, ios and android) are a unique resource that makes you save a lot of time when deploying.  Great course. Great instructor. It deserves more than 5 stars.

results.content: This is a great course for people who would like to have a "hands on" experience. The pace is just perfect to follow along. A descriptive goal is given before each task is started so you know what you're going to do and why you're doing it. This makes it really easy to pause it for a moment and try it out first by yourself and then follow along with how Danny did it. If you're a Vue.js fan you should definitively have a look at this course as it has all you need for developing an app with transitions, proper css and the likes. It's also using lots of technologies you'll be grateful to know. Things like Vuex, Quasar components, Quasar directives, Quasar tools, Firebase, .... Definitely worth the money and time. You won't be disappointed!

results.content:
First of all, thank you for showing me this amazing framework, Quasar. It's much more than I've ever wished for when I first started Vuejs. I was able to create the basics of the project I was dreaming of in a matter of days, I just need some css adjustments. Everytime I look at the documentation I discover something useful. It's an all in one solution and the dev team is very very very supportive. I feel like I should support them in some way. 
Second, the way you've created the Vuex store allows pluging it to other projects and this saves a huge amount of time. 
And third, seeing a real person's face enhances the learning experience greatly.
So thank you for this great course. I'm looking forward to seeing more.

results.content:
The course is really great, by far it covered all my expectations, it immediately goes down to the code step by step, doing a great explanation of quasar, by building a real app.

A lot of courses work with imaginary scenarios to explain things, but in reality it is very different when you are building a REAL product to target from single codebase several platforms. This course goes through all of it.

I'm not new to Vue, and I was surprised to learn a lot of things of Vue in this course.

It goes in great detail with cordova, xcode, android studio, electron, and all that stuff that is hard to learn on your own because information on that is not very easy to search and there are not very good tutorials out there on cordova and electron for Quasar.

Also shows that Quasar is a great and a really powerful tool.

Really good course in my opinion!!!.

results.content:
TL;DR;  
Updated at half course, my opinion is invariated: it need 6 stars to be honest with the quality of this course This course is a rare piece of perfect teaching. And you MUST absolute follow this course because Quasar is mature, efficient, working, stable and excellent. 

This is the only course I taken on 4 years where I can really build one code base and see in action over ALL of what is existing at the moment. Great ! Simply great !

Not only you will learn Quasara, but your will boost your Vue.js knwoledge, learning mixins, directives, and a few other 'less-known' feature of Vue.js, like Vue.set, that I have not previously used.

Techer is excellent, very good speaking, he doesn't loose time in useless chats, BUT , for example in the vuex module, he explains a bit of theory before start coding, and he does it using an animated infographic to shwo both the usefullness and the real-world working of vuex. Great !!!

Pace is perfect, not too rapid and not to slow. If you have 2 monitor you can surely write code while teacher speaks.

Lessons are short, < 10 mins

I love the fact he help use to find answers to our app's needs directly into the documentation; but he doesn't say "look at the doc", he opens, find resources in the doc and show how to use them. Perfect way !!!!

Important: this course is based on a BETA of Quasar but, until now, it's 100000% 1:1 compatible with version I'm using (1.0.5 at today) 

So don't worry for code not working, it simply doesn't happens !

Another good proof of how much is good this course is that there is only few and sporadic questions in te single lectures. No questions means good teaching !

High professionality: teacher is NOT doing wrong, checking way, doing a bit better, refactoring ... no, it's doing well at first shot; I mean, he organized well the vuex store files, do not create a mess and then moved, he writes good code.

Only one suggestion: do not disable ESLint, it's powerfull as teach tool because really force we, the students, to write better code !

response.content: Thanks for your kind and detailed review, Mirko! ?
response.content_html: Thanks for your kind and detailed review, Mirko! ?

Important: this course is based on a BETA of Quasar but, until now, it's 100000% 1:1 compatible with version I'm using (1.0.5 at today)

So don't worry for code not working, it simply doesn't happens !

Another good proof of how much is good this course is that there is only few and sporadic questions in te single lectures. No questions means good teaching !

High professionality: teacher is NOT doing wrong, checking way, doing a bit better, refactoring ... no, it's doing well at first shot; I mean, he organized well the vuex store files, do not create a mess and then moved, he writes good code.

Only one suggestion: do not disable ESLint, it's powerfull as teach tool because really force we, the students, to write better code !

The app I'm working on now will definitely be a Vue/Vuex/Quasar/Firebase app...
